did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Giant Foods, established in 1936, is one of the oldest enduring chains of supermarkets in the U.S., and primarily serves the Washington, D.C. area and surrounding states. The Giant Food Stores Advertising Collection spans the years 1951 through 2001 and includes bound, unbound, and microfilmed volumes of reductions of newspaper advertisements and circulars; oversize posters and banner advertisements; Supermarket News issues from the 1990s; advertising scrapbooks from the 1970s and 1980s; and a set of videotapes of broadcast commercials, that document daily local advertising for a major regional supermarket chain.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials are closed to patron use. Technical Services staff need to produce use copies before contents can be accessed.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. There may be a 48-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Giant Food Stores Advertising Collection, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Giant Food Stores Advertising Collection was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift from the Naomi and Nehemiah Cohen Foundation, and the Jewish Historical Society of Greater Washington, in 2006 and 2010.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Richard Collier and Ali Poffinberger, September 2006
Updated with Acc. 2010-0161 by Meghan Lyon, August 2010
Accessions 2006-0079 and 2010-0161 are described in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: N.M. Cohen and Samuel Lehrman opened the first Giant store in Washington, D.C. in 1936. The store's operating philosophy sought to achieve a price advantage over competitors through a high-volume, self-service operation. As the company expanded, Giant integrated vertically through house-branded products and chain-owned meat packing plants. The company was an early adopter of many of the features now common among contemporary supermarkets, including: automated entrances; shopping carts; computerized inventory control and customer data; and checkout scanners. It was among the first grocery chains to include service centers, such as pharmacies, florists and bakeries, within their stores. Giant eventually expanded into Maryland, Delaware, and Virginia. The chain was purchased by the Dutch company Royal Ahold in 1998, but supermarkets and internet commerce still operate under the Giant name.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Giant Food Stores Advertising Collection spans the years 1951 through 2001 and includes bound, unbound, and microfilmed volumes of reductions of newspaper advertisements and circulars, along with a set of videotapes of broadcast commercials, that document daily local advertising for a major regional supermarket chain.

The collection is arranged by format into eight series: Adbank Commercials; Advertising File; Bound Advertisements; Food World Information Services (FWIS); Microfilm; Scrapbooks; Oversize Advertisements; and Printed Materials. The Adbank Commercials Series consists of videotaped commercials for Giant Foods, and some of its competitors, as compiled by the Adbank research firm. The Advertising File Series includes unbound reductions of Giant newspapers. The Bound Advertisements Series consists of bound volumes of reductions of newspaper advertisements and circulars, arranged by city. The Food World Information Services (FWIS) Series includes reductions of newspaper advertisements arranged by city, as compiled by FWIS. The Microfilm Series contains newspaper advertising archived on microfilm, arranged by city and newspaper title. The Scrapbook Series includes eight scrapbooks with fullpage newspaper advertisements, dating from 1970-1982. The Oversize Advertisements Series include posterboards and banners displayed in storefront windows. The Printed Materials Series includes an incomplete run of Supermarket News, a weekly trade magazine, dating from 1994-1998.

scopecontent.p: Consists of 76 videotapes containing commercials from Adbank's Grocery, Drug, and Convenience Stores Category. Giant Foods as well as competitor commercials are represented. Arranged chronologically and numbered sequentially.

accessrestrict.p: Restrictions on Access: Original videotapes are closed to patron use. Reformatting for use copies is required before material can be viewed. A detailed listing of videotapes resides in the Collection Control File. Contact Research Services for current reformatting procedures and policies.

scopecontent.p: Consists of unbound photocopy reductions of newspaper advertisements. Arranged chronologically.
Consists of reduced photocopies of newspaper advertisements and circulars, arranged alphabetically by city, and thereunder chronologically.

Consists of reduced photocopies of newspaper advertisements, compiled by the Food World Information Service. Arranged into Baltimore-Washington and Philadelphia area groups, and thereunder chronologically.

Consists of 393 reels of newspaper advertisements from a number of cities where Giant operated stores. Arranged into Advertisements, Circulars, and General Merchandise, then alphabetically by city and newspaper title, thereunder chronologically, and sequentially numbered.

scopecontent.p: Includes eight scrapbooks with fullpage newspaper advertisements, dating from 1970-1982.

General fullsize newspaper ads glued or loosely attached to black scrapbook pages. Many feature consumer advocate Esther Peterson, including the following themes:
Discount pricing, Giant goes discount
Unit pricing, Goodbye slide rule
Consumer Bill of Rights
Recycled paper products
Giant brand products
Nutritional labeling, We're making progress
Beef, You have the right to be informed
Giant truckers
Detergents and water pollution
Welcome Home Mr. President, addressed to President and Mrs. Nixon, 1972 Jun 3
We love you Melissa, addressed to Olympic swimming champion Melissa Belote, 1973 Sep 15

General fullsize newspaper ads, including the following themes:
Sugar prices
Immunization
Beef
Halloween

General fullsize newspaper ads glued on beige scrapbook pages, post-bound. Including the following themes:
Discount catalogs and catalog showcase
Giant department stores and store openings in Bowie, Maryland, 1973
Going out of business ads for Giant department stores, 1978
Pants Corral
Fullsize newspaper ads and quarter-page reprints on black scrapbook pages in vinyl, spiral bound book, documenting Somplace Special, Giant Gourmet in McLean, Virginia.

General fullsize newspaper ads on black scrapbook pages in vinyl book, including the following themes:
Seafood
Dairy
Prices and government requested price freeze, 1972 Jan 3
Heidi Bakery
Giant brand products
Open dating
Open letter to Washington Redskins football team after a victory over the Cowboys, 1971 Oct 6
Giant truckers, Driving is a civic duty

General fullsize newspaper ads on black scrapbook pages, including the following themes:
Best wishes to President Nixon on inauguration day, 1973
Open letter to President Nixon, We are grateful...by bringing the peace we have sought... you have earned our gratitude, 1973 Jan 26
Earth Week
Maryland lottery, Why we're selling lottery tickets, 1978
Meat, Yes we have beef,
Mystery at the meat counter

General fullsize newspaper ads, including the following themes:
Store openings in Alexandria, Baltimore, Frederick
Pharmacy openings and advertisements
General seafood ads
Passover, When the family gathers for a seder, with a list of which stores carry the advertised products
Store closings, Due to the Maryland Court of Appeals decision on 1973 Jan 2, all Giant Food stores in Maryland will be closed on Sunday
General fullsize consumer advocacy newspaper ads and reprints featuring Esther Peterson, on black scrapbook pages in vinyl.

Window posters, consumer advocacy newspaper ads, and advertising posters promoting Washington area events, healthy eating and nutrition, Giant store programs and reward systems, and other general advertisements.

Including general advertisements and promotions.
Now shopping has its rewards
Don't forget to show your card
Steering you towards saving
Save money at Giant with checkout coupons
Take off with US Air
Virginia Wine Festival
Buy Now Play Later/Kings Dominion
Now Selling Kings Dominion
Orioles Sweepstakes World Series 1987
50th Anniversary Ice Capades
2 for 1 at KB Theatre
Washington Flower Show

Includes 29 window posters on board focusing on healthy eating habits. Many advertise the Eater's Almanac or use the logo from Foods for Health pilot nutrition program between Giant Food and the National Institutes of Health. Also includes unbound fullsize consumer advocacy newspaper ads and advertising posters featuring Esther Peterson and Odonna Matthews:
We support HR 9178 Office of Consumer Representation, 1977 Oct 30
Eating right is out of sight
Bicycle safety
Nutritional labeling
Meat, Even the White House can't get filet mignon
Detergents
Cycle-Giant label of recycled paper products
Keep food safe from bacteria
Eat for health-food and cancer risks

did.unittitle: Locally Grown Produce window posters on board, each featuring a color photograph of a farmer with their name and location. No Giant logo appears on the board.

scopecontent.p: Includes an incomplete run of Supermarket News, a weekly trade magazine.
